addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall secretary to her Ma
tie
.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. by my former letters
unto yo
w
, and by
e inclosed to my
L. Treasuro[r
I have written about
e Articles whiche were sent
unto me from her
Ma
tie
and because I suppose
it wilbe imparted unto yo
w
, I will not troble yo
r
H.
to heare it repeted. My
L. Willugh-
bies
answear to
e Placcart is come to many mens
handes in these contreis, bothe in Frenche and in Flem-
mishe.
Barnevelt
himself hath showed it in Coun-
cell, and declared
at if he might be permitted, he
would replie in suche sort, as not only these contreis,
but all England, and other places shall talke of
e
mater. Howbeit
e
Councell
gave no answear unto
him, nor Uttered any token of liking or disliking.
But I would my L. could have liked to have
made some of us that are heere acquainted w
t
his purpose, before
e booke had bin published we
could have putt him in minde of sundrie very
necessary pointes, whiche are ill omitted, tending
to his owne defense, and their reproche. I
thinke yo
r
H. is advertised, of
e
Count Hohenloes
comming hither. I can not perceave that he was
publickly revoked, and yet it is supposed, that he
came not of himself. The most of those w
t
whome
I have talked are of opinion, that he hath bin mo-
ved to returne by some privat persons, who desire
to have
e mariage concluded between the
Coun-
tesse of Bueren
and him, thereby to increase
e
Nobilitie of this contrey, and to make their parti-
cular partie strong w
t
his frindship. There
is also a speeche
at he hath letters from
e
Kinge
of Denmarke
,
e
D of Saxonie
, and some other
princes of Germany to her Ma
tie
. To what
fol.3v
effect I can not learne: but it hath bin bruted, at
they are to req
e
st of her Ma
tie
, a favorable hearing of
those causes, in w
ch
he hath bin touched in these contreis:
wheruppon the report hath gone w
t
in these fewe daies,
that he would dispatche a gentleman to her Ma
tie
w
ch
yet I understand is not greatly liked of by some
at are heere. He is departed this
day towardes
Gorc hum
to
Count Maurice
, for that
e
Ennemie is said to have made his approches to
Huesden.
It is understoode this day from
Schincke
that
e 28 of the
last
moneth he encountered w
t
e Enemie
marching towardes
Friseland,
about
Halteren
on
e
borders of
Westphalia,
and defeated 7 Enseignes
of footmen, and 3 Cornets of horse, w
ch
he putt all
to
e sworde, but
at there escaped about
e nomber
of 40 horsemen: and as he himself writeth, his bootieof Jewels, plate, mony and other thinges of price,
was very riche, besides 500
horse
of one sort and other,
whiche he caried away. Of his owne companies,
there was not one slaine in
e Conflict, nor more
then three hurt,
at died shortly after.
And thus
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Aug 2. 89.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
